Award.AbstractNarration: When we run our fingers across a finely textured surface, small, complex vibrations are elicited in the skin, and specialized receptors embedded in the skin allow us to sense these vibrations. Different surfaces elicit different vibrations, and it is on the basis of these differences that we are able to discriminate silk from, say, satin. The ability to extract meaningful information from skin vibrations implies neural mechanisms that have yet to be discovered. This project investigates the mechanisms by which information about surface texture is extracted from texture-elicited vibrations. To this end, the Principal Investigator records (using a laser Doppler vibrometer) the skin vibrations elicited by everyday textured surfaces and examines the information conveyed. He then records the responses evoked by various textured surfaces in the nerve of Rhesus macaques and has human participants perform discrimination experiments using these same textures. Exploiting the well-documented homology between human and Rhesus sensory systems, he uses a variety of computational and machine learning techniques to reveal which aspects of the neural response account for our ability to distinguish between textures. Ultimately, the processing of skin oscillations constitutes a distinct and poorly understood mode of somatosensory processing. Indeed, while analogies have been drawn between visual and tactile processing of shape and motion, this second processing mode draws strong analogies with the auditory system. In both systems, stimulus information is extracted from spectrally complex oscillations (of the ear drum or the skin for audition and touch, respectively). In addition to their important scientific implications, results from this project will inform the development of sensorized upper-limb neuroprostheses and of virtual haptics displays. Finally, the project comprises an important educational and outreach component, with a strong emphasis on undergraduate education, recruitment of under-represented groups, and outreach to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

The overarching objective is to understand the neural basis of touch. Texture offers a unique perspective into tactile coding because it operates over a wide range of spatial scales -- from submicron to millimeter --, engages all types of tactile fibers, and involves several different types of neural codes: rate-based, temporal, and spatial.

To address the texture coding in the nerve, we first collected several large vibrometry data sets in which we characterize the skin response when textures are scanned across it. Second, we collected a large neurophysiological data set in which we recorded the responses of tactile nerve fibers in anesthetized Rhesus macaques to textured surfaces scanned across the skin at different speeds and with different contact forces using a custom designed stimulator. Third, we collected several large psychophysical data sets in which we characterize the perception of texture in human subjects. Finally, we developed a simulation of the entire nerve that allows us to reconstruct, with millisecond precision, the responses of every tactile nerve fiber that innervates the palmar surface of the hand to any stimulus impinging upon the skin.

Impact

1. We have shown that the temporal patterning in spikes, both in the nerve and in the somatosensory cortex, convey stimulus information and shape tactile perception.

2. We have shown that texture perception relies on two distinct mechanism: Coarse textures are represented in spatial patterns of activation, fine textures in temporal patterns of activation. Somehow, these two types of representations are seemlessly integrated to yield a unitary percept of texture, a process that is being actively investigated in the lab.

3. While the response of tactile fibers to textures is highly dependent on exploratory parameters like scanning speed or contact force, the perception of texture is invariant with respect to these parameters. This implies a process by which this invariance is achieved, a process that is being actively investigated in the lab.

4. The dominant analogy has been of touch with vision, with the suggestion that the two systems are spatial senses. Our results suggest that the somatosensory system is also in some ways analogous to audition: information about fine textural features is extracted from skin oscillations in precisely temporally patterned spike trains in tactile fibers, analogous to the conversion of oscillations of the basilar membrane in the cochlea into patterns spike trains in auditory fibers. Furthermore, the invariance of tactile texture with respect to scanning speed requires an analogous computation as does the invariance of timbre with respect to fundamental frequency. We wrote a piece in current opinions in neurobiology, along with auditory coding expert Xiaoqin Wang, on the similarities between audition and touch. 

5. We have developed a very precise simulation of the whole nerve that allows us to reconstruct, with millisecond precision, the response of every tactile fiber that innervates the palmar surface of the hand to any stimulus that impinges upon the skin. With this model, we can now investigate how stimulus information is distributed over populations of nerve fibers. This model can also be used to convert the output of sensors on a bionic hand into patterns of electrical stimulation of the residual nerve to elicit intuitive and naturalistic artificial tactile sensations. 

6. Our work on texture is having a major impact on industries that rely on products that have a tactile component, for example the textile industry or the paper products industry. Indeed, we have established the principles that can be leveraged to design products that are pleasant to the touch or that have specific tactile qualities. We were even involved in the translation of our work into a product during a 4-year long collaboration with Kimberly Clark Corporation.

7. Our work on texture is also having an impact on the mobile device industry: The basic scientific principals we have gleaned in our research are informing the development of touch displays that convey tactile information beyond the vibrations. That work has spawned another NSF-funded project on created virtual textures with mobile displays (with Ed Colgate at Northwestern University). 

8. TouchSim is being implemented by several laboratories developing bionic hands that can feel. This model constitutes a major innovation in the development of artificial touch.

Products

From this project, we have published 22 papers (with three more currently in review) and presented 14 poster presentations at major scientific conferences. In addition, Prof. Bensmaia has given 81 invited lectures and seminars during that project period, most of which covered at least in part work on this project.

Training

Postdoctoral fellows and graduate students have learned to collect vibrometry, neurophysiological, and psychophysical data and to analyze these data using cutting edge computational neuroscience and machine learning approaches. Many undergraduates contributed to this work and are co-authors on the resulting papers.
